Award.AwardTitle: Effector Recognition and Molecular Activation of an Arabidopsis NLR Immune Receptor Specifying Disease Resistance to Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis
Award.AbstractNarration: Plants face continuous attacks by pathogenic microbes and rely on a sophisticated immune system to ward them off. Central to this immune system are intracellular resistance proteins that recognize microbe-derived effector proteins and induce physiological changes in the plant cell that ultimately lead to localized cell death and containment of the invading pathogen. This project aims at investigating in more detail one such resistance protein/effector pair RPP1/ATR1 in the model system Arabidopsis/downy mildew and to gain a better understanding of the molecular events involved in effector recognition and resistance protein activation. The investigators will use genetic and biochemical approaches to obtain definitive evidence for direct interaction between RPP1 and ATR1. Isolation of pure protein extracts of resistance proteins has been challenging, thus the investigators will employ in planta expression systems to obtain enough RPP1 protein to perform direct interaction studies with ATR1 through co-crystallization and protein pull-down experiments. Random mutagenesis of both resistance and effector proteins will provide an exhaustive map of amino acid residues that are crucial for the interaction of these proteins. Precise timing and localization of resistance proteins is imperative during an immune response. RPP1 contains signal sequences that target the protein to the nucleus and/or membrane. In this project the investigators will determine the effect of mutating these signal sequences on RPP1-mediated resistance. Finally, resistance protein activation will be studied using biochemical approaches to identify proteins associating with RPP1 prior to and upon effector recognition. Taken together, results from this project will enhance our basic understanding of plant disease resistance signaling, which may ultimately be translated into agricultural research and result in more sustainable approaches of crop protection. The project will provide training for pre- and post-doctoral fellows as well as undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plant pathogens have evolved suites of effector proteins that are introduced into host cells to facilitate pathogen virulence.  Resistance to such pathogens is conferred by the recognition of effectors by immune receptors known as nucleotide-binding leucine-rich repeat (NLR) proteins.  This genetic resistance is critical to modern agriculture, yet the molecular bases for effector recognition and subsequent immune activation are still poorly understood.  

 

To clarify these issues, we studied an NLR protein, RPP1 (Resistance to Peronospora parasitica) encoded in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana, which recognizes the effector ATR1 from its natural oomycete pathogen Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis.  RPP1 contains a number of domains that are conserved across many NLRs, including a C-terminal leucine-rich repeat (LRR) domain that is involved in effector recognition, a central NB-ARC domain that acts as a molecular switch to control NLR activation, and an N-terminal TIR domain that stimulates an immune response that includes localized host cell death.  The major emphasis of this project was the elucidation of the individual and collective contributions of these domains to RPP1 function.

 

A first outcome of this grant established surfaces of the ATR1 protein that contribute to recognition by the RPP1 receptor.  Enabled by the crystal structure of the ATR1 protein, we mutated the ATR1 gene and mapped substitutions that allowed ATR1 to be recognized to surfaces of the effector.  We isolated mutations that specifically activate each of four RPP1 variants and mapped these to distinct surfaces of the ATR1 protein.  Oomycete effectors often have a similar domain architecture as the ATR1 protein, and thus the ability of an NLR to recognize multiple surfaces of a tandem WY domain protein informs how NLRs could recognize important pathogens in nature.  Importantly, this finding also demonstrated that the two RPP1 alleles, previously identified in different Arabidopsis varieties, have distinct ranges of effector mutants that they can recognize, rather than being differentially sensitized variants of the same receptor.  These data were presented in a paper in the journal PLoS Pathogens (Steinbrenner et al. 2015)

 

In a second focus of this grant, we successfully defined constraints and variation in the RPP1 LRR recognition in its contribution to receptor function.  Previously, our lab had shown that the LRR domain is sufficient to interact with ATR1 in planta.  Thus, the simplest model for full-length RPP1 receptor function was that an LRR domain would be sufficient for specific ATR1 recognition -- e.g. could confer its full range of recognition specificity to a receptor.  Chimeric RPP1 proteins, with an LRR domain from one RPP1 variant but TIR-NBARC from a different variant, disproved this hypothesis.  Instead, a chimeric receptor required both LRRs and an ARC2 domain from the same allele for full sensitivity.  This finding is summarized in Fig. 1 at right and was published in the PLoS Pathogens paper (Steinbrenner et al. 2015).  We also characterized new RPP1 variants from different Arabidopsis varieties Zdarec-1 and Estonia-1.  Surprisingly, these RPP1 variants functioned similarly in binding ATR1, but had massively enlarged LRR domains with 10 additional repeat units.  This implies that future efforts to engineer LRR domains could make use of truncating or extending LRRs to tune specificity.  This finding was published in the journal New Phytologist (Goritschnig et al. 2016)

 

Beyond the LRR domain contribution to effector recognition, we also examined the interactions between domains that are required for the activation of immunity (cell death) by RPP1.  We found that RPP1 oligomerizes upon ATR1 recognition, which has only previously been observed in one other plant NLR.  Interestingly, the TIR domain by itself elicits cell death, and this activity depends on the ability of this domain to self-associate.  Allelic variation in TIR domain autoactivity was used to define specific amino acids that influence self-association and cell death activation.  We also documented self-association of the NB-ARC and LRR domains, and used structural data from animal NLRs to identify a potential intermolecular binding interface in the NB-ARC domain.  In addition, we observed TIR:NB-ARC, TIR:LRR, and NB-ARC:LRR interactions which likely function to negatively regulate RPP1 in the absence of ATR1.  These data allowed us generate a model of the intra- and intermolecular interactions that characterize the pre- and post-activation states of RPP1.


In summary, we have dissected how one NLR receptor binds and activates in response to its cognate pathogen effector.  This project has intellectual merit in contributing to a growing literature on how NLR receptors are activated.  The project has also had broader impacts by contributing to the training of 5 undergraduate students, 1 graduate student, and the dissemination of knowledge in 3 peer-reviewed articles and 1 review.  The project has also had broader impacts on the scientific community and public by facilitating multiple journal articles, conference presentations, undergraduate and graduate student trainees, and elementary school science demonstrations.
